zoopedia_animalcarcass.text:
The dead bodies of whole animals, including fur, skin, and bones, are often fed to carnivorous animals which enjoy the challenging of having to work to "unwrap" their meal to find the best parts.
Artificially-built animal carcasses are used as "containers" for feeding large chunks of meat or fish to carnivores. Guests enjoy watching the animals eat from these more interesting containers.

zoopedia_browseholder.text:
A browse holder is an 8-10 ft. pole with a container on top that is designed to hold grass, hay, and large, leafy tree branches. The positioning of food in this high location encourages
giraffes
and other large animals to feed in a posture that is similar to the one they use in their natural environment.

zoopedia_elevateddish.text: An elevated food dish enables taller animals, like giraffes, to reach their food more easily. Since animals can eat from it while standing, an elevated food dish also aids digestion in many four-legged animals.

zoopedia_fooddish.text: A food dish is an all-purpose food and water container that can serve the needs of all types of animals and dietary choices. A food dish cannot accommodate as many animals as a trough and will need to be refilled more often.

zoopedia_trough.text: A food trough is a large all-purpose food and water container that can accommodate multiple animals at a time. The trough holds more food than the fooddish and will not need to be refilled as often.
